items.abstract: <jats:p>An assessment of health status of winter triticale grain obtained from a longterm reproduction experiment was performed in 1993-1994. Grain from six generations of triticale was examined each year. In both years of the study, the most frequently isolated fungus was Alternaria alternata. The number of isolated pathogens as well as the total extent of grain infestation by fungi depended on the weather conditions during the vegetative growth of triticale plants. There was no correlation between the generations of triticale and fungal infestation of triticale grain.</jats:p>
title: Communities of fungi in grain from several generations of triticale

items.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
<jats:p>The present paper covers a review of documents that specify measurement methods of voltage waveform distortion. It also presents measurement stages of waveform components that are uncommon in the classic fundamentals of electrotechnics and signal theory, including the creation process of groups and subgroups of harmonics and interharmonics. Moreover, the paper discusses selected distortion factors of periodic waveforms and presents analyses that compare the values of these distortion indices. The measurements were carried out in the cycle per cycle mode and the measurement methodology that was used complies with the IEC 61000-4-7 norm. The studies showed significant discrepancies between the values of analyzed parameters.</jats:p>
title: The Influence of Measurement Methodology on the Accuracy of Electrical Waveform Distortion Analysis

items.abstract:
<jats:p>Abstract</jats:p>
        <jats:p><jats:bold>Background. </jats:bold><jats:italic>Swertia perennis</jats:italic> (Gentianaceae) is a perennial diploid and clonal plant species found discontinuously distributed in the peat bogs in mountains of Europe, Asia and North America as well as in European lowlands. The current geographical dispersion of <jats:italic>S. perennis</jats:italic> is probably an effect of Quaternary climatic changes that played an important role in determining the present-day distribution of <jats:italic>Swertia</jats:italic> and numerous other plant and animal species.</jats:p>
        <jats:p><jats:bold>Methods.</jats:bold> A presented survey of molecular studies based on combined data from chloroplast DNA markers (<jats:italic>trn</jats:italic>L-<jats:italic>trn</jats:italic>F and <jats:italic>trn</jats:italic>H-<jats:italic>psb</jats:italic>A) that were conducted to elucidate the phylogeography of <jats:italic>S. perennis</jats:italic> in European localities. Plants were collected from 28 populations that represent different localities in lowlands as well as in mountain areas of Europe (Carpathians, Sudetes, Bohemian Forest and Alps). The cDNA sequences were statistically analysed according to phylogenetical relationships in between specimens collected in separate localities.</jats:p>
        <jats:p><jats:bold>Results.</jats:bold> During the study, 20 haplotypes were characterized representing a high level of genetic variability, but showing a lack of phylogeographical structure. This pattern can be a result of repeated recolonization and expansion from several areas. Such genetic differentiation may also have been due to the relatively long-term isolation of <jats:italic>S. perennis</jats:italic> in Pleistocene refugia in Europe, resulting in independent separation of different cpDNA phylogenetic lineages.</jats:p>
        <jats:p><jats:bold>Discussion.</jats:bold> The lack of phylogeographical structure makes it impossible to indicate the centre of haplotype diversity, but refugia located between the ice sheets in the lowlands, Carpathians, Sudetes or the Alps are the most probable sites, where <jats:italic>S. perennis</jats:italic> existed in Europe. The lack of evidence for phylogeographic structure possibly indicates a high level of gene flow in the recent. The variation in nucleotide composition of cpDNA may reflect the genetic variability from the ancient period, when the landscape and the fen systems were not fragmented, especially on the lowlands, however, at present, it is difficult to speculate about relations between northern and mountain parts of its distribution range in Europe.</jats:p>
title: Phylogeography of Swertia perennis in Europe based on cpDNA markers

items.abstract:
<jats:p>Abstract</jats:p>
        <jats:p><jats:bold>Background. </jats:bold><jats:italic>Swertia perennis</jats:italic> (Gentianaceae) is a perennial diploid and clonal plant species found discontinuously distributed in the peat bogs in mountains of Europe, Asia and North America as well as in European lowlands. The current geographical dispersion of <jats:italic>S. perennis</jats:italic> is probably an effect of Quaternary climatic changes that played an important role in determining the present-day distribution of <jats:italic>Swertia</jats:italic> and numerous other plant and animal species.</jats:p>
        <jats:p><jats:bold>Methods.</jats:bold> A presented survey of molecular studies based on combined data from chloroplast DNA markers (<jats:italic>trn</jats:italic>L-<jats:italic>trn</jats:italic>F and <jats:italic>trn</jats:italic>H-<jats:italic>psb</jats:italic>A) that were conducted to elucidate the phylogeography of <jats:italic>S. perennis</jats:italic> in European localities. Plants were collected from 28 populations that represent different localities in lowlands as well as in mountain areas of Europe (Carpathians, Sudetes, Bohemian Forest and Alps). The cDNA sequences were statistically analysed according to phylogenetical relationships in between specimens collected in separate localities.</jats:p>
        <jats:p><jats:bold>Results.</jats:bold> During the study, 20 haplotypes were characterized representing a high level of genetic variability, but showing a lack of phylogeographical structure. This pattern can be a result of repeated recolonization and expansion from several areas. Such genetic differentiation may also have been due to the relatively long-term isolation of <jats:italic>S. perennis</jats:italic> in Pleistocene refugia in Europe, resulting in independent separation of different cpDNA phylogenetic lineages.</jats:p>
        <jats:p><jats:bold>Discussion.</jats:bold> The lack of phylogeographical structure makes it impossible to indicate the centre of haplotype diversity, but refugia located between the ice sheets in the lowlands, Carpathians, Sudetes or the Alps are the most probable sites, where <jats:italic>S. perennis</jats:italic> existed in Europe. The lack of evidence for phylogeographic structure possibly indicates a high level of gene flow in the recent. The variation in nucleotide composition of cpDNA may reflect the genetic variability from the ancient period, when the landscape and the fen systems were not fragmented, especially on the lowlands, however, at present, it is difficult to speculate about relations between northern and mountain parts of its distribution range in Europe.</jats:p>
title: Phylogeography of Swertia perennis in Europe based on cpDNA markers
